--- title: Welcome to `ndpretty` keywords: fastai sidebar: home_sidebar summary: "Your little helper to display numpy ndarrays in a pretty table in Jupyter notebooks." description: "Your little helper to display numpy ndarrays in a pretty table in Jupyter notebooks." nb_path: "index.ipynb" ---
{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Jupyter notebooks are a great way to develop. ndpretty makes it even better for people who use numpy by providing nice formatting of ndarrays.

Install

pip install ndpretty

How to use

The default configuration is loaded as simply as this:

{% raw %} 
ndpretty.default()
{% endraw %}

After this line has been exectued, all cell outputs that are np.ndarray or torch.Tensor are automatically formatted by ndpretty.

{% raw %} 
a = np.random.rand(20, 30, 2)
a

20×30×2 float64 ndarray















    {% endraw %}






Why? 
Normally, ndarrays look like this in a Jupyter notebook:








    {% raw %}
    







    


a = np.random.rand(20, 30, 2)
print(a)



    

















[[[0.67332527 0.34687068]
  [0.38336068 0.34281941]
  [0.1953115  0.2203909 ]
  ...
  [0.41523347 0.14889802]
  [0.35095522 0.27271219]
  [0.93926387 0.83926031]]

    {% endraw %}






At least to me, that's quite hard to read. Using ndpretty they look like this:








    {% raw %}
    







    


np.random.rand(10, 20)



    

















10×20 float64 ndarray
